text.p: Here are the highlights from Swiss newspapers on Tuesday:
- The Swiss government plans to revise laws governing the Swiss National Bank, requiring it to pass on more of its profit to the cantons and the central government in future.
- Switzerland wants to pass laws mandating a 10 percent reduction of carbon dioxide emissions by the year 2010.
- Ares Serono, the third largest pharmaceuticals group in Switzerland, reported an 18.7 percent rise in 1996 sales to $805 million. Its net profit rose 82 percent to $53.5 million.
- Zurich Insurance Group acquired a minority stake in Thai Metropole Insurance Co. Ltd. in Thailand.
- The European Commission is investigating whether or not the takeover of the French reinsurance firm SAFR by Swiss Reinsurance violates competition laws.

- The Swiss government approved a 1.5 billion Swiss franc defense budget for 1997 and confirmed that defense spending will continue to decline as the government looks to reach its 1990 goal of a 32 percent spending cut by the year 2000.
- Societe de Surveillance (SGS) posted a 12.4 percent 1996 sales increase to 2.954 billion Swiss francs. Net profit rose by 14 percent to 262.7 million Swiss francs.
- A total of 18,116 new cars were sold in Switzerland in February, 6.5 percent fewer than in February 1996.
- SAirGroup is taking over the Belgian Restobel Group.
- United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan presented a restructuring plan which calls for the elimination of some 1,000 U.N. jobs, 200 of which will be in Geneva.
